sols_html:
Let \(\displaystyle g(x,y) = x^{2} + y^{2} -4\) be the constraint function. We thus need to solve the system of equations given by

\[\begin{aligned} g(x,y) &= 0\\ \nabla f(x,y) &= \lambda \nabla g(x,y)\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in our values gives

\[\begin{aligned} x^{2} + y^{2} -4 &= 0\\ (-6xy,6-3y^2-3x^2) &= \lambda (2x,2y)\end{aligned}\]

Expanding the second equation gives the following three equations

\[\begin{aligned} x^{2} &= 4-y^{2}\\ -6xy &= 2\lambda x\\ 6 - 3y^2 - 3x^2 &= 2\lambda y\end{aligned}\]

Substituting the first equation in the third equation gives \(\displaystyle 6 - 3y^2 - 3(4-y^{2}) = 2\lambda y\) which simplifies to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -6 - 3y^2 + 3y^{2} = 2\lambda y\end{aligned}\]

Reducing gives \(\displaystyle -3 = \lambda y\). This tells us that \(\displaystyle \lambda \neq 0\) and thus we can divide by it to get that \(\frac{-3}{\lambda} = y\).

Looking at the second equation from the group of three above gives us that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 0 = 2\lambda x + 6xy = x(2\lambda + 6y)\end{aligned}\]

Case 1: x = 0

Plugging x = 0 into \(\displaystyle g(x,y)\) gives \(\displaystyle y = \pm 2\).

Case 2: x \(\neq\) 0

In this case we divide the equation above by x and obtain

\(2\lambda = -6y = -6\left(\frac{-3}{\lambda}\right) = \frac{18}{\lambda}\)

Solving gives \(\lambda = \pm3\). Thus \(y = \frac{-3}{\lambda} = \mp 1\). Plugging these y values into \(\displaystyle g(x,y)\) gives \(x = \pm \sqrt{3}\).

Compare function values at all candidate points

We found the following six solutions:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (0,-2), (0,2), (-\sqrt{3},-1), (\sqrt{3},-1), (-\sqrt{3},1), (\sqrt{3},1)\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in each of the values gives

\[\begin{aligned} f(0,2) &= 6(2) - (2)^3 - 3(0)^2(2) = 4\\ f(0,-2) &= 6(-2) - (-2)^3 - 3(0)^2(-2) = -4\\ f(-\sqrt{3},-1) &= 6(-1) - (-1)^3 - 3(-\sqrt{3})^2(-1) = 4\\ f(\sqrt{3},-1) &= 6(-1) - (-1)^3 - 3(\sqrt{3})^2(-1) = 4\\ f(-\sqrt{3},1) &= 6(1) - (1)^3 - 3(-\sqrt{3})^2(1) = -4\\ f(\sqrt{3},1) &= 6(1) - (1)^3 - 3(\sqrt{3})^2(1) = -4\end{aligned}\]

and thus the minimum value is -4 and the maximum value is 4.

statement_html:
Use the method of Lagrange multipliers to find the maximum and minimum values of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = 6y - y^3 - 3x^2 y\end{aligned}\]

on the circle

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x^2 + y^2 = 4\end{aligned}\]

A solution that does not use the method of Lagrange multipliers will receive no credit, even if the answer is correct.
